factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: The Canal Club site, a former wood wharf, was purchased by the Greater London Council (GLC) in the 1970s and given to the Wellington Estate in Tower Hamlets as an extension for recreation. By the 1980s and 1990s it had become an important local resource, housing a community centre, which provided a laundry, youth club, nursery and play and amenity space.

In 2010 a community garden was built to provide a safe, outdoor space for local residents without access to their own garden. The garden is open to the public during the growing season and residents all year round. It hosts arts events and gardening workshops free of charge and provides a meeting space for local groups in the borough, from NHS nurses to student film makers.

factsheet.heading: Under threat of imminent demolition
paragraphs: Save our Space E2 are campaigning to save the Canal Club community site from demolition and redevelopment by Tower Hamlets Council. We are campaigning for refurbishment of the site to protect the environment and provide much needed amenities for the local community.

SOS E2 opposes Tower Hamlets plans because they will result in a loss of the original, architect designed hall, play, amenity and community gardening green space. These plans will also lead to a further increase in the building density of the area.

factsheet.heading: The architect Julain Sofaer
paragraphs: The architect Julian Sofaer, who died on May 30th 2017 at the age of 92, was known for his work of community facilities, schools and colleges. From the Hugh Myddleton School in Islington, The Meridian West (private house) in Greenwich to smaller scale works such as the Community Hall - known as The Canal Club - purchased by The Greater London Council in the late 1970's  as an extension to the Wellington Estate, London E2.
Julian, a highly principled modernist, a great lover of music and the arts, obsessed with form and harmony, left an indelible mark on our urban landscape.
